detail.content: Visual Citizenship: Belonging through the Lens of Human Rights : Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content          < back        Visual Citizenship: Belonging through the Lens of Human Rights  VISUAL CITIZENSHIP As newspapers and magazines falter, losing their financial footing and overwhelmed by competing online resources, documentary photographers have increasingly sought a more independent approach. Rather than relying on mainstream media to present their own points of view in a credible way, they are coming up with a variety of new strategies—books, exhibitions, postcards, multimedia, facilitating the work of local photographers, etc.—finding that the viewers they reach may respond differently, and sometimes more deeply, to work done outside the warp speed of the 24-hour news cycle. This is not a completely new phenomenon—photographers such as Don McCullin and Philip Jones Griffiths made devastating comments on the Vietnam War, for example, via books that they had published—but in these complex and chaotic times, where good and evil are not always easy to separate, photographers have found it not only useful but necessary to invest in working methods that allow for complexity, emphasize the actuality of their subjects, engage readers more fully, and assert their own responsibility as witnesses and fellow citizens. The work exhibited here from the Tisch School of the Art’s Department of Photography & Imaging’s students, alumni and faculty, reflect a more nuanced view of recent events and ongoing situations. Jessica Ingram ’s A Civil Rights Memorial makes evident how the secular is so easily allowed to override the sacred, restoring our memory of those victimized by racism; Joseph Rodriguez ’s Still Here: Stories After Katrina , contests the mainstream focus on the spectacular with the enduring, emphasizing individual will; Robert Sukrachand ’s 74th and Roosevelt affirms the individuals and their histories lost in the generic label of “homeless”; Peter Lucas ’s work on Viva Favela in Brazil embraces self-identification as a powerful human right; and Alan Chin ’s conflicting readings of Chinese society through his own search for self weave the personal and idiosyncratic into the simplified public in Hollow Wealth: The Chasm Between Money and People in China . The work by professors Erika deVries and Lorie Novak with New York high school students under the umbrella of the Community Collaborations program furthers a sense that what can be taught must be shared, and the lens of looking points in multiple directions, and not only physically. In the histories of photography it is often the subject who is rendered paradoxically invisible, denied agency. Hopefully in this work it is not only the subjects who emerge, but the citizenship of both viewers and photographers who, rather than voyeurs, prefer to be counted among those who exercise their obligations to their fellow human beings. Study Abroad Summer High School Summer in New York City Programs for Visiting Students Open Arts Minors Blog Events Newsletters Videos Admin & Faculty Alumni Contact Us  home > Special Programs        Through the Documentary Lens: Human Rights  OART-UT.1704 Lecture 4 Credits Instructor(s): Aviva Slesin This course is designed for students with an interest in exploring Human Rights through viewing and discussing documentaries. In this class we will view both new and classic documentaries about Civil Rights, Gay and Lesbian Rights, Prisoners’ Rights, Women’s Rights, Children’s Rights and Immigrants’ Rights. The course will cover different perspectives as well as provide insights into both the subject matter contained in the films and the techniques and skills of good documentary filmmaking. Through research, weekly screenings of films, class discussions and invited guest filmmakers, students will learn about both the evolution of the documentary genre as a means of better understanding history, and gain knowledge about the historical/political/cultural milestones and the heroes of the Human Rights movement. Invited guests will offer personal perspectives and add depth and context to the films and subjects screened. Check Albert for course schedule. Under what circumstances are people in crisis seen, but not heard, in public? In what ways do visual practices condition who belongs and who does not belong to a political community? How is belonging to a political community accomplished visually? Why does seeing human rights and humanitarian crises matter? This conference explores these and other questions about the links between visual arts, public communication, human rights, and humanitarian action. The aim is to recast citizenship as more than a legal property or juridical frame. Instead, invited speakers consider the ways in which imagery and organized spaces effect how people realize their place in a political community and manage what they do about it. What we see, how we see it, according to whom, and where contribute to the way people in crisis debate meaningfully about how they are governed.
